description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Målet med insatsen är att individer, grupper i civilsamhället, kyrkor och institutioner bidrar till förbättrad social samexistens genom att på ett fredligt sätt lyfta bekymmer hos gruppen. Det huvudsakliga syftet med insatsen är: • Främjande av fredlig samexistens, ömsesidigt förtroende, och icke-våldsamma medel för konfliktlösning (detta inkluderar förändrade attityder mot varandra genom att jobba med historiska händelser och trauman, och att få färdigheter för att lösa konflikter fredligt). • Att främja fredliga sätt att uttrycka sitt missnöje på, och kräva sina rättigheter genom att uttrycka sina åsikter på ett konstruktivt vis.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The goal of the intervention is for individuals, CS groups, churches and institutions to contribute to improved social co-existence and to peacefully raising the social concerns of target groups. The main objectives of the intervention are: • Promoting peaceful co-existence and mutual trust, and promoting nonviolent means for Conflict Resolution (this includes changing the attitudes towards the other, dealing with historical grievances and trauma, and gaining the skills to resolve conflicts peacefully) • Promoting peaceful means for the communities to express their grievance and demand their rights through using their Voice constructively

description.narrative: Results achieved is presented in the annual report for 2020, which is for the new programme officer to follow up on, but following are examples of achievements, which are also presented in the Conclusion of Performance for 2020. Whereas the first year (2019) of the project focussed on Outcome 1, where all planned activities for that period was implemented, the second year (2020) delivered on all three outcomes. One of the main outputs of 2020 is the Training of Trainers (ToTs) sessions that have taken place in all five project zones, reaching more than 150 change agents in local churches and communities. The ToTs have built on the Peace building manual that was produced during the first project year. Another achievement is the Trauma recovery manual, which have been produced and written tailor-made for training of lay councillors in trauma recovery in a Christian setting. This manual will be utilized for ToTs during the third project year. Examples of achievements under each outcome: Outcome 1: Improved capacities of the evangelical churces to respond to peace needs in their communitites and to address ethnocientrism in churches and society. - National level peace conference conducted in March 2020. Particpants included ECFE regional structures, community gatekeepers, denomination leaders and Ministry of Peace. Exampel of direct result from the conference was f ex an initiative by one participant to organise a training on conflict resolution in Bule Hora, Guji. - A TV production on "role of women in Peace buidling" was realised and aired on Walt TV. - Gate keepers' conferences with 150 participants in 5 zones; Bench Sheko in SNNP, West Guji and Shashamane in West Guji in Oromia. To a large extent, the conferences reach out especially to youth. - Training of Trainers (ToT) of local peace builders. A total of 154 trainers took part in the ToTs that was based on the peace manual developed during year 1 of the project. The trainings include that each trainer develop their own action plan to reach out to their respective communitites. To a large extent, the ToTs reach out especially to youth. - Development of a manual for trauma counseling, which will be the foundation for Training of trainers in trauma recovery during the remaining project years. Outcome 2: Women church leaders and women in communities are active in peace building, conflict resolution and trauma healing. PMU reports that it has been a challenge to involve a larger number of women in the project activities because of traditional structures and misconceptions. Work still remains to raise various stakeholders’ awareness and to enhance women's participation, but an encouraging sign of improvement is noted. - The TV production on "role of women in Peace buidling" mentioned above has put the issue on the agenda and triggered discussions on peace and the importance to involve women in peace work. - The most important goal is to include women in the regular work for peace and dialogue and not building parallel structures. However, the a few activities directly addressed women’s participation and gender equality in peace building. One of these interventions is the “Gender equality and the role of women in peace building” seminar that was carried out in each of the project target zones with a total of 151 participants, with the aim to create awareness on gender equality with traditional and religious perspectives. At the end of those seminars 5-7 local female leaders where recruited. Outcome 3: Evangelican churches strengthened to engage with stakeholders to advocate for peace in the communitites. - Three project’s advisory committee (AC) meetings have been conducted during 2020. The AC is essential to both firmly establish the project in the ECFE member churches, and to receive advice from the representatives. - Capacity development of implemnenting partners through trainings in peace building and conflict sensitivity; outcome harvesting for reporting; and project management. Some unexpected results include: - A taskforce established following the Gatekeepers' conference in Bench Sheko zone. The taskforce has assessed the prevailing conflicts in the Bench Sheko zone, mapped the conflict zones, and developed an action plan with the budget. The Bench Sheko Zone Administration has accepted the Strategic/action plan with slight modification and promised to fund some of the activities. - A taskforce established following the conference in Shambu, Horo Guduru, with the main aim to periodically gather to discuss peace and security issues in their area and working with government agents to develop solutions. - ECFE was given the opportunity to, in collaboration with Ahadu Radio and Television, organize a panel discussion on the topic of Youth and Peace, which was broadcasted live on radio, with a condensed version aired on Ahadu Television. Challenges and major events during 2020 * The COVID-19 pandemic presented its first case in Ethiopia in March 2020, and in early April the Federal government declared a state of emergency. As for most partners in the country, the effects of the pandemic and the restrictions on such things as travel and meetings, posed major challenges on the programme.PMU, in consultation with the programme officer at the embassy, showed flexibility in adapting activities to ensure continued implementation; meetings and trainings were f ex conducted in larger halls and with relevant C19 prevention. In addition, PMU added COVID-19 mitigation measures like distributing hand-washing kits and information material in the areas of implementaiton, which was positively received and proved to help in creating trust by the communities. * Increasing violence and tensions in most part of Ethiopia has affected the project, mainly by the violence in Oromia region since three of the project implementation areas are found there. The most serious of these events took place in June 29 when a famous Oromo singer activist was assassinated. Following the death of the artist, youth in almost all parts of the Oromia region began to protest, and several hundred people were killed. Another project area where large scale violence has broken out is Guraferda in Bench Sheko zone in SNNP region.Some activities have been slightly postponed due to sudden violent outbreaks in project areas. The vast church network of our implementing partner ECFE has proven to be an asset when navigating in violent areas and for gathering necessary information to take relevant security precautions. * Altough the project is not implemented in Tigray, PMU notes that also the war in Tigray that started early November 2020 pose a risk and potential challenge to the project, due to the growing uncertainty in the country.
